answers.answer: OK...First, why would you delay going to the bathroom to take a pee?  And, I'm just guessing here, but if you're doing that, are you perhaps on the couch with your feet up?  Just asking for more info...

delaying going to the bathroom is not good for your bladder, infection can arise. Ans the tingling is probly a nerve reaction and if its gone after u go then don't do it u silly. Your body talks to u, listen to it and u just might ward off the possibility of and infection.

Ok guys and/or gals that responded to my question, there are many reasons for not immediately responding to the urge: if I am driving and must wait to get to a location that has a restroom; I am in a business meeting and want to wait for the appropriate time to excuse myself; or, any other number of circumstances that any one of us encounters on a daily basis (unless you may be swimming with the dolphins and urinate about every fifteen minutes, as was reported as the average frequency of a case study I read about in a scientific journal article back in the late sixties or early seventies).I was diagnosed with borderline diabetes about four years ago and have managed to keep it under control with weight loss, moderation of carbohydrates and healthy diet, and exercise.  I just thought there may be some connection that someone else had experienced.  FYI, I also have an enlarged prostrate.The key point to note here is that the need to urinate sometimes comes quickly and at a time when I am forced to hold it and have a strong urge to go - that is the time when I get a tingling sensation.So, if I mayanticipate your next respones relative to your last ones, I should just go with the flow and enjoy the sensation.

question: When I delay going to the bathroom to urinate, my feet begin to tingle.  What is the cause?
title: Feet tingling associated with delayed urination
